case_vignette: A 36-year-old woman comes to the ph   ysician because of a 12-month history of upper abdominal pain. The biopsies from these ulcers were negative f   or H  . pylori. Current medications include pantopra   zole and over-the-counter antacids. She app  ears anxious. multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Gastrointestinal System. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been experiencing upper abdominal pain, especially after eating, along with nausea, heartburn, and multiple episodes of diarrhea.
How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?
I have been experiencing these symptoms for about a year.
Do you notice that symptoms worsen with fatty or spicy foods?
Yes, my pain gets worse after eating.
Have you lost any weight unintentionally recently?
The details about weight loss aren't specified in my situation.
Do you have a history of alcohol use or smoking?
My history of alcohol use or smoking isn't mentioned in my details.
Have you previously been diagnosed with any gastrointestinal diseases or disorders?
I underwent an upper endoscopy which showed several ulcers in my stomach and small intestine, but biopsies were negative for H. pylori.
Final Diagnosis: Peptic Ulcer Disease.
